Award.AwardTitle: AmeriMech Symposium: Mechanical Behavior of 2D Materials (Graphene and Beyond); Austin, Texas; April 4-6, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding support for the AmeriMech Symposium on Mechanical Behavior of 2D Materials (Graphene and Beyond) to be held in Austin, Texas from April 4-6, 2016. This AmeriMech Symposium will bring together experimental and theoretical researchers interested in the mechanical behavior of 2D materials in order to develop a comprehensive view of the state of the art, and develop a roadmap for future research.

Low-dimensional materials play an increasingly critical role in advanced technologies. The mechanics of deformation and failure of these materials have been recognized by the mechanics of materials and structures community as an extremely challenging problem, both to predict computationally and to measure experimentally. This symposium will bring together leading researchers in the field of low dimensional materials. The longer presentation times, coupled with a substantial discussion period at the end of each day will foster meaningful exchanges between participants and lay the groundwork for the development of a roadmap for future research and collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since the first successful synthesis of graphene just over a decade ago, a variety of two-dimensional (2D) materials (transition metal-dichalcogenides, hexagonal boron-nitride, and so on) have been discovered. Among their many unique and attractive properties, mechanical properties play important roles in manufacturing, integration and reliability for potential applications. The coupling between the mechanical and other physical properties (thermal, electronic, optical) is also of great interest in exploring novel applications. Mechanics of 2D materials has emerged as a critical area but has yet to become a major player in the broader research community addressing 2D materials. The title of the symposium is given above and reflects the AmeriMech series of symposia sponsored by the US National Committee of Theoretical and Applied Mechanics. The symposium brought together experimental and theoretical researchers interested in mechanical behavior of 2D materials in order to develop a comprehensive view of the state of the art and a roadmap for future activity.

The symposium was held from April 4-6, 2016 at the AT&T Conference Center at the University of Texas at Austin. There were 30 registered attendees, including leaders in different aspects (theory, synthesis, mechanical behavior) of research into 2D materials who were invited as speakers. Postdoctoral fellows and graduate students were invited to attend the sessions and participate in the discussion periods that were held at the end of each session.

The major outcome of the project is the dissemination of information presented at the symposium. A web presence was established for the symposium at https://www.ae.utexas.edu/~ruihuang/AM2016/, which includes the schedule and the abstracts of presentations. In addition, a review article co-authored by a group of 14 of the 26 presenters at the symposium has been published in Extreme Mechanics Letters (vol. 13, pp. 42-72, 2017; DOI: 10.1016/j.eml.2017.01.008). This article was accompanied by a collection of two perspective papers written by participants and five full-length articles in a special issue on the subject. All the articles have been reviewed and accepted for publication in the special issue of Extreme Mechanics Letters in 2017.


Last Modified: 04/03/2017
Modified by: Kenneth M Liechti
